subj-group.subject: Symposium on Welfare Reform under the Labour Government: Part I

title-group.article-title: Social Security in the UK under New Labour: What Did the Third Way Mean for Welfare Reform?

abstract.p: In 1997, the Labour Party was elected in the UK with few explicitly articulated ideas about social security reforms. This paper reviews the large number of subsequent reforms to social security, and argues that some consistent themes have emerged. A commitment to keep to the tight spending plans of the previous, Conservative, administration left little scope for increases in benefit spending during the first two years in office. Since that time, increases in the generosity of some social security programmes have been directed towards achieving certain goals. An emphasis on encouraging paid work has been a consistent theme, whilst aims of reducing poverty rates for children and pensioners have been emphasised since 1999. Spending to achieve these goals has often been directed through means-tested programmes, and there has been a related weakening of the link between paid National Insurance contributions and benefit entitlements. It remains to be seen whether reforms to the process of income assessment will increase take-up.

There has been an almost continual programme of incremental changes to the conditions attached to receiving out-of-work benefits, so few sources review them all. Many of the incremental reforms are described in chapter 4 of successive Budget documents. One of the main legislative changes was the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 (see House of Commons Library (1999a)). Other sources are Department for Education and Employment (2001a and 2001b) and HM Treasury and Department for Work and Pensions (2001) on JobCentre Plus, and Bennett (2002) on joint claims for jobseeker's allowance.

lt is interesting to note that the flat-rate system envisaged by Beveridge (1942) did not involve different people paying different amounts of contributions in return for different entitlements. This became a feature of the UK National Insurance system later, especially after the introduction of SERPS in 1978. We do not consider this further, but for some discussion of how contributory benefits evolved in the UK after the Second World War, see Social Security Select Committee (2000).
Although there is currently a commitment to increase the value by at least 2.5 per cent a year, even if the price-inflation rate is lower than this.

This should be made flat-rate if and when it is considered that 'stakeholder pensions have established themselves' (Department of Social Security, 1998b). For more on S2P, see Agulnik (1999), Disney, Emmerson and Tanner (1999) and House of Commons Library (1999a).

For example, the target to reduce the number of children in poverty by at least a quarter by 2004 is to be assessed against a 1998 baseline with poverty defined as living in a household with income below 60 per cent of the median (Department of Social Security, 2000a). Much of the government's supporting analysis and thinking also uses this definition (see HM Treasury (1999b)).

The unit of observation is the household. Incomes are measured before housing costs are deducted and are adjusted for household composition using the McClements scale (see Department for Work and Pensions (2002a, appendix B)). The modelled effects are estimated using the IFS tax and benefit simulation model, TAXBEN, using data from the 1999/2000 Family Resources Survey. The estimates therefore take no account of changes in the structure of the population or in the underlying income distribution during the period in which the modelled reforms took place.

We do not model changes to employers' National Insurance, nor some of the reforms to bereavement benefits and incapacity benefit, partly because data limitations make it difficult to model these benefits and partly because the reforms affect new claimants only. We do not have the expertise to model tax changes that are not formally incident on households.

2000/01 is the latest year for which such data are available. Some of Labour's important tax and benefit reforms were already effective by this date, but some, including a large increase in the minimum income guarantee for pensioners and the new credits, were not.

But note that the results from the extremes of the income distribution may partly reflect the way in which the Households Below Average Income data-set is constructed: the bottom decile of the data-set contains a high proportion of people whose reported income over the relevant period seems to be much lower than their usual income (for example, durable ownership and reported income tax liabilities are higher in the bottom decile than in the second decile — see Clark, Giles and Hall (1999) for more details on this); the incomes of the very rich are also thought to be less reliable in this data-set, though they are adjusted in an attempt to make them more accurate (see Department for Work and Pensions (2002a, p. 249)).

See Piachaud and Sutherland (2001), although the figure for children is confirmed by other studies cited in Brewer, Clark and Goodman (2002a). The latter reference also discusses in more detail why earlier estimates of the fall in child poverty under Labour were higher than the outcome.

Total social security expenditure includes some items that are not benefits in the usual sense — for example, Pensions Compensation Board funding. These will typically be included in the 'non-contributory, non-means- tested' category. Statutory sick pay and statutory maternity pay are included with contributory benefits as they are funded from the National Insurance Fund, although they are not, strictly speaking, dependent on National Insurance contributions. The pre-1988 maternity grant should logically also have been counted as contributory, but has usually been in the 'non-contributory, non-means-tested' category. Sure Start maternity grants are part of the income-related Social Fund. See footnote 3 for the children's tax credit. Source: Department for Work and Pensions, personal communication.
